title: The Rise of Private GP Practices in the UK
summary: This article examines the growing trend of general practitioners (GPs) opting to work outside the UK's National Health Service (NHS). Dr. Yvonne Girgis-Hanna, a GP, shares her experience of finding NHS work exhausting due to high patient loads and administrative tasks, leading her to split her time between NHS and private practice. Data from the Care Quality Commission (CQC) reveals a significant increase in registrations for independent consulting doctors, with a 212% rise over five years and a 58% jump from 2024 to 2025. A report estimates that private GP consultations have grown from 3% to 13% over two decades. The article explores reasons for this shift, including doctor burnout and patient demand for quicker or specialized care. Independent doctors cover various specialties, and while exact numbers for private GPs are unclear, the trend highlights challenges in the NHS system and changing healthcare preferences.

background_read: This article discusses healthcare in the UK, focusing on the NHS, which provides free medical services, and the rise of private GP practices. GPs are family doctors who handle common health issues. The CQC regulates healthcare quality. In recent years, more doctors are registering to work privately due to factors like burnout from NHS workloads and increasing patient demand for prompt or niche services. Understanding this trend helps explore issues in public healthcare systems and how private options are evolving to meet needs.
Article_Structure: Main Points: The article highlights a sharp increase in GPs working privately, driven by doctor burnout from NHS workloads and patient demand for quicker care. Data from CQC shows registrations rose 212% over five years. Purpose: To explain why this shift is happening and its implications for healthcare. Evidence Evaluation: Uses CQC data and a LaingBuisson report, providing credible statistics, but notes limitations in isolating private GP numbers. Author Credibility: BBC News is a reputable source, but the article relies on expert quotes and reports rather than original research. Methodology: Analyzes regulatory data and includes interviews with practitioners to gather insights.

perspectives.description: The trend reflects strain on the NHS, with doctors seeking better work conditions and patients turning to private options for efficiency.
